title: Arctic Blast Brings Snow and Health Alerts to UK in 2026
summary: As 2026 begins, the UK is experiencing an Arctic blast, leading the Met Office to issue snow and ice warnings from New Year's Day through the weekend. This cold spell, expected to last over a week, poses significant risks including travel disruption with potential large snow accumulations and blizzards. Overnight temperatures have plummeted to as low as -9.6°C in Braemar, Scotland, marking some of the lowest readings this winter. In response, the UK Health Security Agency has upgraded cold health alerts to amber for all of England, effective until January 6. These alerts highlight increased dangers, such as higher mortality rates among elderly and vulnerable populations, challenges in maintaining warm indoor environments, and risks in healthcare settings. While New Year's Eve may be dry for most areas, snow showers are forecasted for northern Scotland and other regions, accompanied by strengthening northerly winds that exacerbate the cold feel. Maximum temperatures are projected to range from 0 to 7°C before dropping further, emphasizing the need for public awareness and preparedness during this extended period of severe weather.
